etymologies: mid 16th century (in appendix (sense 2)): from Latin, from appendere ‘hang upon’ (see append). appendix (sense 1) dates from the early 17th century

notes.text: Appendix typically has the plural appendixes in the anatomical sense, and appendices when referring to a part of a book or document

definitions: a tube-shaped sac attached to and opening into the lower end of the large intestine in humans and some other mammals

examples.text: I'm merely standing in while Stella is having her appendix out

notes.text: In humans the appendix is small and has no known function, but in rabbits, hares, and some other herbivores it is involved in the digestion of cellulose

shortDefinitions: tube-shaped sac attached to and opening into lower end of large intestine in humans

definitions: a section or table of additional matter at the end of a book or document

examples.text: a list of such activities was published as an appendix to the report
outline answers may be found in Appendix 2

shortDefinitions: section or table of subsidiary matter at end of book or document
